document.masterDocTitle: A Revision of the New Zealand Endemic Rove Beetle Genus Agnosthaetus Bernhauer (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A Revision of the New Zealand Endemic Rove Beetle Genus Agnosthaetus Bernhauer (Coleoptera: Staphylinidae)

mods:name.mods:affiliation: Zoology Department — Division of Insects Field Museum of Natural History 1400 S Lake Shore Drive Ch; Department of Biological Sciences — Ecology and Evolution Group The University of Illinois at Chica

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type Material. Holotype .
♂ , with three labels: “New Zealand DN| Woodside Glen [ 45°51′S 169°55′E ]| 50 m , 19 Oct 1981 | J.C. Watt| Litter 81/106/ FMNH-INS 0000 038 398 / HOLOTYPE
Agnosthaetus newtoni Clarke
, ♂ , design. D. Clarke 2011”, in NZAC.
Paratypes .
86 specimens ( 41♂ 42♀ 3 unsexed).

Diagnosis. In addition to the characters mentioned in the description of the
thayerae
speciesgroup,
A. newtoni
may be distinguished from
A. thayerae
by the combination of labrum with medial ridge and lacking the medial oblique labral setae ( Fig. 20 , mo ), and median lobe with distinctly truncate apex, with large apicolateral teeth ( Fig. 169 , cf . Fig. 167 ).

Description. Color : Variably reddish brown, occasionally with darker pigmented abdominal segments ( Fig. 8 ). Head : Frontal ridge absent. Dorsum sparsely punctate; with punctures distributed over entire surface except for small medial impunctate region. Punctures deep, well defined; diameter subequal to or slightly greater than diameter of eye facet; interpuncture distance mostly less than half puncture diameter. Dorsal microsculpture present on entire or most of surface; distinctly reticulate, fainter posteriorly. Dorsal tentorial sulcus ( cf . Figs. 10–11 , dt ) distinctly slit-like; width subequal to or less than puncture diameter. Sublongitudinal ridge ( cf . Fig. 10 , sr ) distinct; confused by punctures; crest at antennal tubercle with distinct microsculpture. Area above and behind antennoocular carina ( Figs. 10–11 , arrow) with single subsidiary carina formed by confluent punctures. Antenno-ocular carina joining eye at about middle. Temple ( Fig. 11 , tm ) short, less than 50% EYL. Subocular surface more or less evenly microsculptured ( cf . Fig. 65 ). Labrum with medial blunt carina; distinctly sexually dimorphic ( Fig. 166 ). Apical labral margin in males broadly convex, smooth mesially, dentate only laterally, with 4–12 teeth ( n =11), all teeth normal, projecting more or less anteriorly. Apical labral margin in females broadly convex, not emarginate medially; with 18–21 teeth ( n =8), all teeth subequal in length. Medial oblique labral setae ( cf . Fig. 20 ) absent. Adoral labral surface in males with subapical, transverse ridge ( Fig. 166 , arrow). Mandible sexually dimorphic; males with 2 mesal teeth, 1 directed dorsally and 1 mesially ( Fig. 189 , arrow), without preapical spur ( cf . Fig. 189 ); females with single, mesially projecting tooth, without spur. Labium angulate anterolaterally. Prothorax : Pronotum with distinctly reticulate microsculpture. Medial pronotal sulci anteriorly separate from, and terminating posterior to anterior punctures; basally separated from basal foveae, or continuous with basal foveae ( cf . Fig. 23 , bf , ms ). Distance between medial sulci subequal along entire length, or very slightly greater posteriorly. Pronotal basolateral carina distinct ( Fig. 73 , bp ). Pronotal macrosetal punctures distinct ( cf . Fig. 73 ). Medial pronotal seta subequidistant from medial and lateral sulci ( Fig. 73 , mu ). Pronotal hypomeron ( Fig. 24 , hy ) with distinct reticulate microsculpture. Prosternum with faintly reticulate microsculpture. Pterothorax ( Fig. 88 ): Elytron ( Fig. 23 , e ) with distinct microsculpture; with 2 macrosetae, set in distinct punctures; laterally with two ridges ( Fig. 88 , ek , mr ). Mesothoracic epimeral region ( Fig. 24 , mer ) with distinct microsculpture. Metathoracic pleural region ( Fig. 24 , m ) with distinct reticulate microsculpture. Metathoracic pleural ridge present ( Fig. 88 , mp ), fully developed; metathoracic pleural groove ( Fig. 24 , gr ) incomplete posteriorly, forming elongate oval punctiform impression. Abdomen : Abdominal vestiture long, dorsally with radiating fans of setae either side of midline, and laterally. Abdominal sternite IV of male with surface glabrous and very slightly impressed apicomedially; V with surface narrowly impressed apicomedially, flanked by dense coarser setae, the apex of the sternite distinctly thickened; VI with surface glabrous apicomedially, surrounded by coarser setae. Aedeagus ( Fig. 169 ): “ Type B” (see description on p. 8; but with apparent secondary sclerotization; Fig. 169 , ssc ). Apical part of medin lobe subtruncate, with distinct apicolateral tooth-like lobes and minute medial tooth. Apicolateral setae small; apicomedial setae small at middle, and up to 5X longer along margin ( Fig. 170 ); shaft setae present (but difficult to see). Paramere exceeding apex of median lobe; in lateral view produced apically into lobe; with apical part perpendicular to median lobe; and with paramere fused to median lobe for most of length; with 4 small setae arranged in a line subapically.

Etymology. The specific name
newtoni
is a noun in the genitive case, honoring Al Newton in recognition of his contributions to rove beetle systematics and evolution, particularly in the staphylinine group of subfamilies (which includes
Agnosthaetus
).
Distribution. ( Map 6 ). South Island: CO; DN; MK; SL.

Biology and Ecology. Habitat: forested habitats; tussock grassland. Specimens have been taken in a variety of litter, moss, soil, and flood debris. Phenology: Year-round. Elevation:
10– 975 m
.
